Violence erupts in troubled state of Chechnya

Chechnya returned to it's violent past last week when Islamic terrorists attacked the republic's parliament in the capital Grozny (Thumbnail credit The Russian Prime Minister played a key role in installing the current Chechen President. Photo credit: World Economic Forum)

Osborne's bold gamble

Nouse Politics team assesses the Comprehensive Spending Review: prudent cuts or reckless gamble? (Thumbnail credit Osborne, has been accused of risking many jobs in the biggest macroeconomic gamble of a generation. Photo credit: Conservative Party)

Cuts and strikes: Europe's repetitive theme

The wave of protests and industrial action across Europe is expected to continue as Government spending cuts are announced (Thumbnail credit Recent strikes by underground staff caused commuter mayhem. Image credit: C. G. P. Grey)

So much for Miliband's 'New Generation'

Last week Ed Miliband made his first major decision after becoming Labour leader (Thumbnail credit New Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer Alan Johnson with Labour candidate for York Outer James Alexander, in Westminster. Image credit: time-4-change.org.uk)

Private Life Politics, Should it Matter?

Following Ed Miliband's recent election as Labour leader, controversy has erupted surrounding his personal life (Thumbnail credit Bill Clinton's presidency was marred by private scandals. Image credit: SSKENNEL)

Osborne botches child benefit reform

It has been an uncomfortable week for the Chancellor George Osborne, after his announcement that Child Benefit would be cut for all those earning over PS44,000 was met by outcry from both outside, and within, the Conservative Party (Thumbnail credit Osbourne has received a heavy amount of criticism after his child benefit reforms seemed to lack sophistication. Image credit: Conservative Party)

18 months on, Guantanamo bay still open

Around nine months ago, Barack Obama missed his self-imposed deadline for closing the U.S. prison camp at Guantanamo Bay (Thumbnail credit A Humvee patrols Guantanamo Bay. The facility remains open despite Obama's promises. Image credit: The US Army)

Political Edge

Peculiar Vince Cable (Thumbnail credit Vince Cable MP. Image credit: say_cheddar via Flickr Creative Commons)

Why Labour needed the other Miliband

Unless you have purposefully dodged all forms of media, then you will know by now that Ed Miliband is the new leader of the Labour party. Ed scrapped to victory by a minuscule 1% margin over his brother David, following heavy support from trade unions (Thumbnail credit Image credit: pennycsa via Flickr Creative Commons)

Controversy rages over 'Ground Zero Mosque'

As the ninth anniversary of 9/11 approaches, people all over America are gearing up for a show of solidarity (Thumbnail credit Artistic rendering of the proposed Park51 centre, referred to by some as the &quot;Ground Zero Mosque&quot;)

UK foreign aid: one step forward... about a million backwards

As with the entry of any new government, most departments go through a series of reforms post-election. The Department for International Development (DFID) has been no exception to this

To the left, or to the right?

In recent weeks the Labour leadership race has slowly but surely began to gather some pace. Unsurprisingly, the Miliband brothers have begun to emerge as front runners (Thumbnail credit Image credit: pennycsa via Flickr Creative Commons)

Are the Liberal Democrats suffering an identity crisis?

The look of excitement on Nick Clegg's face was hard to contain. A couple of weeks ago he took Prime Minister's Questions while David Cameron was off visiting the Obamas, and his glee at standing at that dispatch box could not have been more obvious

Building the 'big society' on the 'little people'

The term 'summer holiday' does not apply to the many weeks students have stretched before them before University starts again. Instead, this period should be called 'the summer where you save the world and enhance your CV' (Thumbnail credit Photo: Conservatives via Flickr Creative Commons)

Global Focus

The <em>Nouse</em> Politics team summarises the biggest stories from around the world

More killed as Mexican drug violence escalates

The bodies of 12 people have been found in a cave near the popular tourist resort Cancun in Mexico (Thumbnail credit Police on patrol in Cuidad Juarez, the world's murder capital. ; Scazon)

Belgian unity under threat after election

The new Flemish alliance (N-VA), a Flemish nationalist party, has won the most seats in the Belgian parliamentary elections, increasing their haul from four at the last election to 2 (Thumbnail credit Bart de Wever, leader of the N-VA party, has been at the centre of attention on Belgium following his election success. ; Luc Van Braekel.)

Violence in Kyrgyzstan leaves hundreds dead

UN Officials have suggested that a million people were caught up in the ethnic riots and fighting between ethnic Kyrgyz and Uzbeks in southern Kyrgyzstan (Thumbnail credit Some people in southern Kyrgyzstan have been forced to leave ; Gusjer)

Political Edge

Free Schools? I'm sceptical

BP faces criticism from Congress

The Chief Executive of BP, Tony Hayward, last week had to withstand heated questioning over the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico (Thumbnail credit Gas from the Deepwater Horizon rig is burned by a drillship. ; Dvidshub)

Tensions between Kenyan tribes resurface

Six people have been killed and dozens injured at a rally in Nairobi, when crowds stampeded following two explosions (Thumbnail credit Kenyan riot police during previous unrest in 2007. ; Demosh)

Bloody Sunday report finally released after 12 years of waiting

David Cameron has apologised for the events of Bloody Sunday following the findings of the Saville Inquiry. The Prime Minister spoke in parliament of the 'shocking conclusions' of the report, which stated in absolute clarity that the British Army were at fault for the atrocity (Thumbnail credit Bloody Sunday memorial in Derry, Ireland; Photo: Wikimedia via Creative Commons)

Global Focus

The <em>Nouse</em> Politics team summarises the biggest stories from around the world

The death of the Euro Zone: crisis and conflicts

It was only a few years ago that countries were falling over each other to try and gain entry into the prestigious 'Euro club' (Thumbnail credit The Euro is steeply declining in value against other currencies; Photo: Eric Caballero)

Leadership contest begins in earnest

Several Labour MPs have announced their candidacy for the upcoming leadership contest (Thumbnail credit David Miliband is currently the favourite to succeed Gordon Brown as Labour leader, but he faces stiff competition, including his brother Ed; Photo: World Economic Forum)

Coalition could prove fractious for Tories

THE CONSERVATIVE PARTY is under more pressure now than at any point since the late 90s (Thumbnail credit Cameron may struggle to prevent divisions over the coalition, Photo: The Prime Minister's Office)

Political Edge

Trying to fight a controversial immigration law? Who do you turn to for assistance? Naturally, the first port of call is popular children's cartoon character Dora the Explorer

Tea Party candidate wins primary

LAST WEEK, Rand Paul, an outsider candidate with little experience, won the Kentucky Republican senate primary against the establishment favourite Trey Greyson (Thumbnail credit Sarah Palin is a key figure in the Tea Party movement, Photo: asecondhandconjecture)

Special relationship not so special after all?

Barack Obama was the first Head of State to call David Cameron, suggesting that the relationship between the UK and the USA might be on the mend after Obama's previous rebuffs towards Gordon Brown

The <em>Nouse</em> Politics team blog the 2010 General Election results live
